Boston counted its homeless people on Monday night, on a night when temperatures were arctic cold. "This a way to put a face and a number to the needy, and the most effective way to canvass your area tonight is to imagine yourself in the shoes of a homeless person," said Jim Greene, who coordinated the volunteers who gathered to conduct the city's 34th annual homeless census. Last year, 6,992 homeless people were counted -- a 5.2 percent increase from 2011. That number included 193 homeless people who were counted on the streets, 12 more than in 2011.

Ashley Collins, 21, a former foster child with no family to help pay for college, works three jobs while trying to stay in school. This year, she switched colleges, and now does her schoolwork at home, in her pajamas when she feels like it. But this is not one of those trendy online classes everyone is talking about. It's more radical: a real, accredited degree program with no classes at all, not even online. No teachers, just academic coaches. And a price tag of $2,500 a year. Story: http://b.globe.com/187DsBt

GLOBE SPOTLIGHT INVESTIGATION: Most taxis in Mass. operate with the state minimum bodily injury coverage of $20,000. That's a fraction of what most motorists buy for their own cars. Bicycle messenger services are required to carry $50,000 in insurance.

And it's allowed because the Legislature has repeatedly ignored proposals to mandate more insurance for taxis. Full story: http://b.globe.com/10skvUm 

Pictured here: Boston Cab owner Edward J. Tutunjian has by far the biggest taxi fleet in the city, controlling 1 in 5 of the 1,825 licensed taxis. (Globe staff photo / John Tlumacki)

Animal rescuers from the New England Aquarium rescued a six-week-old seal pup today from a beach in Hull. Rescuers were worried the pup would become too stressed by the attention from beach-goers, so they prompted her into a dog kennel and then took her to a natural reserve on the South Shore.  "We teach people to watch from a safe distance," said Tony LaCasse, an aquarium spokesman, who added that the pup did not show significant health concerns. "We really would have preferred to leave this animal alone."

President Obama was sworn in today in a small ceremony in the White House's Blue Room, beginning another four-year term. Chief Justice John Roberts administered the oath of office, while Michelle Obama, and Malia and Sasha Obama, looked on. Vice President Biden took his oath of office earlier today at the Naval Observatory, the official residence of the vice president. Obama and Biden will take the oath of office again in a larger ceremony tomorrow in front of the US Capitol, followed by Obama's inaugural address. http://b.globe.com/13TbbfP

Governor Deval Patrick proposed an increase in the state income tax rate, from 5.25 percent to 6.25 percent, and a decrease in the sales tax, from 6.25 percent to 4.5 percent, tonight in his State of the Commonwealth address. Today is day 5 of our special series, 68 Blocks: Facing the future, or the dream of one http://b.globe.com/RG60x9 
There were 19 shootings in Bowdoin-Geneva this year, but no one was killed. Here, that seems a step ahead. But progress, if real, feels like a fragile reed in a garden furrowed deep with promise and pain.

This series is provided free to non-subscribers as a public service.

Pictured: Jhana Senxian, left, founder of the Coleman Street Neighbors Association, served food in the community garden during a block party in September. (Aram Borgosian for The Boston Globe)

Mayhem has a kind of momentum; it can be exhausting to resist. In Bowdoin-Geneva, an anticrime effort flops. And Big Nate explodes. But the peace festival rocks, and a son in jail has started to pray. 

Read day 4 of the Globe's 68 Blocks series, provided free to non-subscribers as a public service. http://b.globe.com/T6S0L2

INTERACTIVE GRAPHIC The fall and rise of a small Dorchester street http://b.globe.com/ZJ64ya
Hendry Street stretches for just two and a half blocks, but more than any street in Boston it has epitomized both the failures of urban life and the potential for people and government to be forces for good. 

Note: As a public service, access to this series "68 Blocks: Life, death, hope" is being provided at no charge on BostonGlobe.com

On Hendry Street, a new sense of stability is unraveling. On Norton, a gang target plans a peace festival, which police fear will only draw trouble. Nothing is easy in the Bowdoin-Geneva section of Dorchester, but no one is giving in. Story: http://b.globe.com/WlTJvm 

Note: As a public service, access to this series "68 Blocks: Life, death, hope" is being provided at no charge on BostonGlobe.com

Pictured here: Tony Van Der Meer lives along Hendry Street, which has regressed after a few years of seemingly better days. (Yoon S. Byun / Globe staff)

Five Globe reporters spent the year focused on the Bowdoin-Geneva section of Dorchester, a neighborhood often identified with the violence that has erupted there with disconcerting regularity over the decades. 

Faces and voices of Bowdoin-Geneva: http://b.globe.com/VLEr0x 
The Globe selected Instagram photos from the neighborhood over the past few months then asked users to talk about the moments that inspired them.  

Note: All links in the Bowdoin-Geneva special series are available to non-Globe subscribers.

"There is only one thing we can be sure of, and that is the love we have. For our children, for our families, for each other. The warmth of a child's embrace - that is true. … That fierce and boundless love that we feel for them … we know that's what matters. We know we are always doing right when we are taking care of them. When we are teaching them well. When we are showing acts of kindness. We don't go wrong when we do that. That's what we can be sure of.  That's what you, the people have Newtown, have reminded us."
- President Obama
(Wire photo)
Hundreds gathered outside of the Newtown, Conn., high school before a vigil tonight. Globe reporter Martine Powers took this photo.  We are streaming the service live here: http://b.globe.com/P76NFL

Dreams cut short, dreams reborn | It's a neighborhood known for trouble, but Bowdoin-Geneva is much more than that. A Globe team spent months there, listening and asking why violence persists where love and loyalty also run so strong. Part one of a five-part series: http://b.globe.com/T1uTBB

A closer look: This papyrus fragment contains the first known explicit reference to Jesus as married.  Full story: http://b.globe.com/V8RlYE 

A Harvard professor has identified what appears to be a scrap of fourth-century papyrus that, while not evidence Jesus was married, shows that some early Christians believed he had a wife. http://b.globe.com/V8RlYE

Harvard professor Karen L. King has identified what appears to be a scrap of fourth century Egyptian papyrus that contains the first known explicit reference to Jesus as married.  

The fragment is smaller than a business card, and appears to have been torn from the middle of a page of a codex, or primitive book, written in a southern Egyptian dialect. Its owner, who declines to be identified publicly, does not know where it was found.

It contains just eight broken lines, scrawled in a crude Coptic hand.

The fourth says: "… Jesus said to them, 'My wife…."

The next line reads: "…she will be able to be my disciple."  More details: http://bo.st/V8QtmQ

Paul Pierce hit a key three-pointer over LeBron James with less than a minute left to help power the Celtics win. (Getty Images)
Here's columnist Bob Ryan on how the Celtics scored the biggest win of the year: http://b.globe.com/L9KoAp

After Tuesday (today), the next transit of Venus won't occur until 2117. If the clouds don't break, almost no living Bostonian will ever see another. Will you watch?
Transit of Venus a once in a lifetime event: http://b.globe.com/Ln5KZq
An architectural rendering of the proposed Suffolk Downs resort casino. http://b.globe.com/L882NJ What do you think of the design? Does it live up to your expectations?
Now your Celtics are headed back down to Miami for Game 5 after getting the job done at home. (Photo: Barry Chin/Globe Staff)
Stunning aerial shot of Boston by Globe photographer David L. Ryan.

2012 New England Weekend Fun Guide: http://b.globe.com/KiOCdJ 
There never seem to be enough weekends in New England's too-brief summer. Here are things to do to make each one fabulous.

Rajon Rondo scored 44 points for the Celtics, who had a 15-point lead in the second quarter, but the Heat stormed back to take a 2-0 series lead. 
Story: http://b.globe.com/KebX04

Mad dash by the grounds crew during a deluge during the eighth inning, which forced a 38-minute rain delay at Tuesday's game between the Tigers and Red Sox.  And the Sox won!
More photos: http://b.globe.com/JtMl9G

More than 12,000 veterans are buried in Mount Hope Cemetery in Mattapan, tucked away on a quiet street and surrounded by trees.  On Sunday, the graves of service members were marked by American flags. Near the site of the ceremony, people could be seen visiting graves and planting flowers.
Story: http://b.globe.com/LXl324
Now it's on to Miami for Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals on Monday night. (Photo: Jim Davis/Globe Staff)

More than 200 volunteers placed over 33,000 American Flags on a hill on the Boston Common.
Story: http://b.globe.com/MNGmSQ

What a 5-year-old's request says about Obama's race role: http://b.globe.com/LdhfXL 
An enduring White House photo shows a black boy touching the president's hair to see if it feels like his.

Harvard's quirky graduation rituals: http://b.globe.com/JZ4dgH 
In celebrating its 361st commencement today, Harvard University will reach back through the centuries to once again summon traditions deep and dear. Here is a look at some of the college's time-honored — and quaintly curious — graduation rituals.

Museum workers prepared a mummy for the ''Lost Egypt: Ancient Secrets, Modern Science'' exhibit, which opens Sunday at Boston's Museum of Science.
More images from the exhibit: http://b.globe.com/LpFYYt

The Harvard alumni directory for the class of 1962, which is celebrating its 50th anniversary, contains a bizarre entry for Ted Kaczynski, the graduate known as the Unabomber. Check out his list of awards.
Story: http://b.globe.com/JHUbBz

State officials will make a network of trails over a century-old system of aqueducts accessible to hikers, bikers, or anyone seeking a stroll in the woods.  Communities will share the land with the MWRA.
Story: http://b.globe.com/KygDYb

After hanging around for most of the game, the Celtics went on an embarrassing 31-12 run that locked up a win and gave them a crucial 3-2 series lead.
Story: http://b.globe.com/KIs5WO 
Pictured: Brandon Bass led the Celtics with a game-high 27 points, 18 of which came in the third quarter.
A brain implant allows two paralyzed patients to control a robotic arm. Did you ever think such a thing was possible? http://b.globe.com/MnHdcy

The legendary Blue Jay Recording Studio in Carlisle, where artists from Boston to Lady Gaga have recorded, is up for sale. http://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2012/05/15/old-school-blue-jay-studio-for-sale/QdYwcciRONSQ3pVKTxUNBI/story.html

Following reports that his video game company was struggling financially, Curt Schilling met with Rhode Island officials today and asked for more money. http://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2012/05/16/schilling-officials-meet-over-game-company-troubles/gFiDBtOBgJcLxy8mwwfsUM/story.html

New MIT president L. Rafael Reif is known for his research on semiconductors and was an early advocate for nanotechnology. Story: http://bostonglobe.com/metro/2012/05/16/rafael-reif-mit-provost-named-president-college/mYSpQuIqmM5j4EabKf5jkL/story.html
Recognize this photo? Then you're probably one of the many drivers getting stuck in the parking lot that is the commute to the Cape. http://b.globe.com/JimjFA

Relatives of Boston University junior Margaret Theriault await an update after she underwent brain surgery in New Zealand, where she was injured in the van crash that killed three students.
Story: http://b.globe.com/Mc7oD8

Boston is home to the oldest existing school in the US. Founded on April 23, 1635, Boston Latin School is also the first public school. It is a public exam school and was attended by many prominent Bostonians, such as: Ben Franklin, Samuel Adams, John Hancock. More photos: http://b.globe.com/K7vpZZ

In the rainforest-covered ruins of a Mayan city dating back more than 1,100 years, a Boston University-led excavation has turned up the oldest evidence of that civilization's mastery of astronomy -- a precise lunar calendar scrawled on what appears to be an ancient blackboard.
Story: http://b.globe.com/KJ2wG2

What do you think of the new asymmetrical fauxhawk Tom Brady debuted at the Metropolitan Museum of Art Costume Institute gala Monday night?
Our fashion writer is not a fan.  Tom Brady: Step away from the hair product: http://b.globe.com/IMQR7I

Dan Wasserman, editorial cartoonist for The Boston Globe, remembers children's author Maurice Sendak.  Sendak, who authored over 50 children's books including "Where the Wild Things Are," died Tuesday at the age of 83.
Editorial cartoon: Mourning Maurice Sendak http://b.globe.com/IU6x92

After 11 years, three Super Bowl titles, four Pro Bowls, and being at the heart of the Patriots renaissance, left tackle Matt Light retired Monday.
Story: http://b.globe.com/KfDBXJ

Though it will never be as popular as the ubiquitous Colonial here in New England, the ranch is making a return. The simple home is being embraced by young people attracted to the mid-century modern vibe; by aging boomers who no longer want to deal with stairs; and, as always, by those looking for an affordable home.
Story: http://b.globe.com/Jrzyp4

QB Tom Brady looked as sharp as ever at this year's Kentucky Derby. He was there - reportedly wearing Tom Ford - with his Pats pal Wes Welker, and celebs such as Ashton Kutcher, "Twilight'' actor Kellan Lutz, and singer Miranda Lambert. But where is his hat?
Story: http://b.globe.com/KHF0Uc

Giza 3D, a free interactive Web app being launched today, will offer the virtual explorer an animated passage through Egypt's Pyramids.
Story: http://b.globe.com/J8lykV
From the Boston Globe archives: The Celtics in the playoffs. http://b.globe.com/IZnc6P

A new plaza debuted Wednesday near Tremont and Park streets that may change what it means to be a park in Boston. The overhaul included more than just new granite and fresh grass. The goal is to give people who pass this corner a reason to stop, sit, and spend time in America's oldest park, the Boston Common. Pictured: The newly renovated Brewer Fountain Plaza on Boston Common. Story: http://b.globe.com/KfhRxV
House hunting? This Nantucket home has a sticker price of $59 million. http://b.globe.com/ILYNk2

We love this photo of Rylee Kipf, 4, of Oklahoma, who spent yesterday with family in the Public Garden. (Globe photo)

The gush of rain ends the months-long dearth of precipitation that has left the state's rivers at record lows and spurred more than 200 brushfires. Story: http://b.globe.com/JpZJ42

The Red Sox toasted Fenway Park's centennial in grand style today in a rousing ceremony in which they welcomed dozens of former players. (Getty Images)
Fenway Park celebrates 100 years: http://b.globe.com/I7zcUz

Happy 100th birthday, Fenway Park!  This photo was taken by Globe photographer David L. Ryan.

Why is Fenway so beloved? Explore in this excerpt from the Boston Globe's keepsake book, "Fenway Park: A Salute to the Coolest, Cruelest, Longest-Running Major League Baseball Stadium in America," on the ballpark's centennial.

BREAKING NEWS: TV host Dick Clark has died at the age of 82, according to a spokesman.

This photo taken by AFP photographer Massoud Hossaini won the 2012 Pulitzer Prize for Breaking News Photography.  On Dec. 6, 2011 Afghan Tarana Akbari, 12, cried near dead and injured people after explosions during a religious ceremony in the center of Kabul.  Several members of her family were killed.

New Bedford artist and devoted Sox fan M-C Lamarre has painted replica Green Monsters in basements, back yards, and on a barn, bringing a piece of Boston folklore to fans across Red Sox Nation.

In honor of Opening Day, here's a stunning aerial shot of Fenway by Globe photographer David L. Ryan.  Go Sox!

If the new UMass license plate passes with the Registry of Motor Vehicles it will become the first charity plate in support of a Massachusetts university or college.

April 16th marks the 116th running of the Boston Marathon. Around 27,000 runners are expected, up from the 15 who ran in 1897. Take a look at scenes of marathons past.

Thousands gathered to play and party at last weekend's PAX East gaming convention at the Boston Convention & Exhibition Center, and on Saturday night about a hundred gamers took the party across the street to the Westin Boston Waterfront Hotel.  Irrational Games, of Quincy, hosted the get-together to thank fans of its 2007 hit, BioShock, and to stoke anticipation for the upcoming sequel: BioShock Infinite, to be released Oct. 16.
Story: http://b.globe.com/HC4N2n

The Tigers claimed an Opening Day win when their walk-off run overcame a ninth-inning Red Sox rally.  How are you feeling about the 2012 Sox?

Still tied 0-0 in the bottom of the 7th. Go Sox!

After the preppy heyday of the 1980s, the Sperry Top-Sider became decidedly uncool. Now, a new generation of shoppers has discovered the brand and made it hip again.

status_message:
Fenway Park, celebrating the 100th anniversary of its opening, has served as a landmark for generations of Bostonians.  In honor of the milestone, we've published a special magazine on the centennial.
Special section / Fenway at 100: http://b.globe.com/H1GFnt (subscription required)

Whatever renovations are made, the generational links remain unbroken, which is why we cherish this place, writes Dan Shaughnessy in a preview of Sunday's special magazine on Fenway Park's centennial.
Story: http://b.globe.com/HuhdHO

Looking for some fresh brunch ideas?  The Globe Magazine staff has picked their top 45 brunch spots in the Boston area.  What's your favorite?  
Pictured: A typical brunch at Deluxe Town in Watertown and Deluxe Station in Newton Centre.
45 best breakfast joints around Boston: http://b.globe.com/HyvSmd

As other residents raced out to save their vehicles from being towed, tow trucks in South Boston's Telegraph Hill twice passed over an SUV owned by US Representative Stephen F. Lynch that was parked in a free overnight spot. 
Story: http://b.globe.com/H1m98S

The brain is crisscrossed by neural highways that follow a simple, grid-like pattern, much like ordered city streets that intersect at right angles, according to new research by Massachusetts General Hospital scientists.
Story: http://b.globe.com/H5bh9F

After years of planning and discussion, the massive Assembly Row complex in Somerville has entered a new phase as developers started construction yesterday on the first two buildings of the $1.5 billion project.  The apartment buildings by AvalonBay Communities Inc. will have 448 rental units, and at 470,000 square feet is one of the largest residential real estate projects under construction in the Boston area
Story: http://b.globe.com/Hkx8qZ

Legally blind, former Red Sox pitcher Lou Lucier, 94, relies on Jerry Remy's analysis as he watches his beloved Sox on the wide-screen TV. But he's quick to offer some analysis of his own. 
Story: http://b.globe.com/HcgD01

Pictured: A man cries while carrying a woman out of the courthouse today.  The jury in the Mattapan massacre trial in Suffolk Superior Court today acquitted Edward Washington on all charges for his alleged role in the murders of four people, including a two-year-old boy, in 2010.  Full story: http://b.globe.com/GNi2Z6

Millions of birth, marriage, and death records from Mass. dating back to 1620 will become available online today on Ancestry.com, thanks to the decades of work by a former Massachusetts couple who spent 30 years traveling from community to community, collecting old documents from city and town halls across the state.
Story: http://b.globe.com/GAASVx

The Patriots signed defensive lineman Jonathan Fanene to a three-year deal. The versatile run-stuffer will likely help alleviate some of the pressure on Vince Wilfork. 

Read more about the newest Patriot: http://b.globe.com/xneTQa

A three-alarm blaze near the Back Bay Hilton filled the air with thick, heavy smoke, knocked out power in the area, and forced the closure of several streets and MBTA stations. 

If the fire is visible from where you are, please tell us what you are seeing in the comments here. Stay safe and thank you.

Latest updates: http://b.globe.com/Aab3u4

Spring's most delectable hues walk the sweet line between pastel and neon.
Shoe inspiration: http://b.globe.com/yd8upP

status_message:
One of the strongest solar storms in years engulfed Earth this morning, but scientists say the planet may have lucked out.
More photos: http://b.globe.com/yR9YHc

In the first unveiling of new hardware since co-founder Steve Jobs died in October, Apple CEO Tim Cook showed off a newer, faster iPad with a sharper display.  Think you'll be making a purchase?
More info: http://b.globe.com/vZzXGq

The much-anticipated Boeing 787 Dreamliner, built primarily of lightweight carbon composite materials, is 20 percent more fuel-efficient than other planes its size and will probably be used mainly for international flights. Something that every 787 passenger is bound to appreciate is the light that fills the plane. The windows are 30 percent larger than on similarly sized airplanes, and it is easy to see out, even from the middle row, without leaning over and craning your neck into uncomfortable contortions.  Pictured here is the view out the window.
Boeing 787 Dreamliner delivers comfort: http://b.globe.com/A1gK4t
Browse through some of the best photos of the week from Boston Globe staff: http://b.globe.com/Akk7mf

Las Vegas casino mogul Steve Wynn this morning released his first renderings of his proposed $1 billion gambling resort in Foxborough, making his pitch to win over the community in a glossy mailing, including a 20-minute DVD, sent to more than 7,000 households.  What do you think of the design?
Story: http://b.globe.com/xE5fdm

Fresh hand-rolled sushi. A juice bar with made-to-order smoothies. A hair and nail salon. It's certainly not a typical drugstore. But these are among the amenities that Walgreens will offer in the former Borders space when it debuts a 24,000-square-foot store this fall in Downtown Crossing.

And "The Artist" wins Best Picture at the 84th Annual Academy Awards.  A good choice by the members of the Academy?

The Esplanade Association unveiled a blueprint yesterday for the 3-mile park that envisions a pedestrian walkway jutting out into the Charles River, an expansive terrace near the Hatch Shell, and a widened bridge over Storrow Drive that would serve as a gateway to the park.  The group is also considering  replacing the parking garage for the Museum of Science with a walkway along the river, or building a Ferris wheel akin to the London Eye.
Story: http://b.globe.com/zPAjlM

Was Gisele Bundchen right or wrong in defending Tom Brady? Op-ed columnist Joanna Weiss and cartoonist Dan Wasserman debate whether Bundchen crossed the line in defending her husband after the Super Bowl.  What do you think?

Stymied by the Giants again, Tom Brady, after five appearances in the Super Bowl, is less than two minutes from a record five rings.  After the game, Brady got a hug from his wife, Gisele Bundchen.

A collective hush fell over sports bars across Eastern Massachusetts as Tom Brady's last-second bomb fell incomplete and the New York Giants defeated the New England Patriots, 21-17.
Story: http://b.globe.com/wLMfpY
Which Super Bowl loss was tougher, tonight or 2008?
Tough loss: Giants 21, Patriots 17.

This was tough to watch: The Giants' Chase Blackburn intercepts a pass intended for Rob Gronkowski.

Fans pulled their hair, gasped, and shouted out in a collective howl of rooter's anguish after the Giants closed to 17-15 and Tom Brady threw an interception. Pictured: Stuart Wax of Brighton cheered at a Super Bowl watching party at Boston University's Agganis Arena.

First-grade students at Higginson-Lewis K-8 School in Roxbury have shown marked improvements in behavior and social development since they were separated into all-girls and all-boys classrooms. status_message:
Ron Paul's second-place finish tonight in the New Hampshire primary gives the Texas congressman much-needed momentum as the campaign heads south, first to South Carolina then Florida.  Paul suggested his campaign is closing in on that of frontrunner Mitt Romney. "We're nibbling at his heels," he told a cheering crowd. 
Story: http://b.globe.com/xUnROW
Happy New Year!
Not everyone will be a party animal tonight. What are your plans to usher in 2012?
link_name: Some Bostonians shun New Year's Eve revelry to quietly ring in 2012 - The Boston Globe

status_message: A group of MIT undergraduates designed HelmetHub vending machines that would dispense headgear to riders of Hubway, Boston's bike-sharing system.
link_name: A vending machine that serves up safety

status_message: Our New Year's Eve dining guide offers choices for lovebirds, party animals, or just kicking back with family and friends.
link_name: Where to party and dine in Boston on New Year's Eve

status_message: Firefighter James M. Rice was remembered today as a "truly heroic'' man whose death has left a "giant hole'' in the hearts of his family and his fellow firefighters in this North Shore city.
link_name: Thousands mourn fallen firefighter in Peabody

status_message: She brought once-mighty House speaker Salvatore DiMasi to justice, the latest in her long-running push to expose and punish political corruption. Now this powerful US attorney has her eyes on James "Whitey" Bulger. For that, Carmen Ortiz is our 2011 Bostonian of the Year.
link_name: Carmen Ortiz is the 2011 Bostonian of the Year

status_message: After Francine Dorrance was evicted from her Chelsea Housing Authority apartment over $276 in unpaid rent, the authority's housing manager moved in, paying $25 a month in rent.
link_name: Chelsea housing tenants suffer, officials benefit

status_message: A snap quiz from today's Opinion section: Who was the most prominent Massachusetts politician to flip-flop on abortion? No, it's not Mitt Romney; it's Edward M. Kennedy.
Recent studies show that a large percentage of patients who are on cardiac monitors do not need to be — an overuse of technology that contributes to alarm fatigue.
link_name: Wide heart monitor use tied to missed alarms

status_message: Three months after suffering horrific burns in Haiti, Dieuphete Celime will get a new lease on life and a functioning face from doctors at Shriners Hospital for Children in Boston.
link_name: Boston burn doctors to help boy from Haiti

status_message: A day after their casino proposal was rebuffed by the town, New England Patriots owner Robert Kraft and casino mogul Steve Wynn refused to back down from their plans for a casino near Gillette Stadium.
link_name: Foxborough casino fight apt to go on

status_message: In an interview at Mul's Diner in South Boston, Senator Brown made it clear that he wants to project an image as an independent Republican who can reach across party lines and that Democratic candidate Elizabeth Warren is far too partisan.
link_name: Brown calls himself 'most bipartisan' in Senate

status_message: Restaurant critic Devra First shares her 11 favorite dishes from 2011.  Pictured here: 62 Restaurant & Wine Bar's confit pork belly with spicy red cabbage slaw.  Yum.

The Supreme Judicial Court today gave its blessing to a novel power purchase agreement between Cape Wind and National Grid, which has already been approved by the state Department of Public Utilities.
link_name: SJC upholds ruling for sale of Cape Wind power to National Grid

status_message: Some local theaters are considering offering "tweet seats" to people who want to tweet during live performances.  Think this is a good move on the part of theaters?
link_name: Local theaters ready to bow to tweeters in the audience

status_message: Last night Foxborough selectmen voted *not* to negotiate with Steve Wynn over terms for having a casino in town.  Does the 3-2 vote against negotiating surprise you?  What would you do if you were in their shoes?
link_name: Foxborough casino proposal is dealt a setback

status_message: Cardinal Sean P. O'Malley's long-awaited list of priests who have been publicly accused of abusing minors left out the names of 70 priests and other clerics simply because they don't work directly for the Boston Archdiocese. To critics, it is a disheartening sign that nearly ten years after Boston became the epicenter of the global sexual abuse crisis in the Catholic Church, the Boston Archdiocese is still struggling to face its troubled past.
link_name: Many alleged abusers left off church list

status_message: A former European lay missionary, Antonio Enrique is now editor of The Pilot and a target of criticism for articles that have opened old wounds for the church.  He published a column two weeks ago suggesting that homosexuality is caused by the devil. The uproar had barely faded when, a week later, The Pilot enraged priest abuse victims with a flattering birthday ode to Cardinal Bernard F. Law, the former Boston archbishop and the public face of the scandal.
link_name: Editor steers church paper into controversy

status_message: Massachusetts is one of only two states in the country without a law granting prison inmates the right to test DNA evidence that might prove their innocence. A lingering, long-contested bill may finally change that.
Today Harvard University will open its innovation lab, an incubator for start-ups intended to infuse the freewheeling ethos of Silicon Valley into America's oldest college.
link_name: Harvard makes foray into start-up scene with i-lab - The Boston Globe

status_message: When the Globe began asking Chelsea Housing director Michael E. McLaughlin about his true salary and why he told the state that it was only $160,000, McLaughlin called Lieutenant Governor Timothy P. Murray each time within hours, according to the phone records.

Mitt Romney's campaign manager is requesting that Governor Deval Patrick's administration provide copies of any correspondence with several of President Obama's top aides. The request comes after a Globe report this morning that 11 of Romney's aides purchased their state-issued hard drives and wiped e-mails from the server at the end of Romney's term in 2006.

status_message: The goal of vthankyou.com, which launches tomorrow, is to leverage social media to honor military veterans. status_message: Public health officials warn that the US caesarean rate, now 33 percent, is alarmingly high. One obstetrician explores why hospitals' rates can vary so widely – from 15 percent to 45 percent in Massachusetts –and whether anyone should care.

There's a painting by the German artist Gerhard Richter called "September.'' Looked at casually, the image seems poised between representation and abstraction: a slightly blurry arrangement of blues and whites and grays, anchored by two vertical rectangles, beneath an unsettling presence of brown-black.  Looking more closely, and with the title in mind, one realizes just how representational it is. The rectangles are the twin towers of the World Trade Center; the brown-black is the pall of smoke that issued from the towers on Sept. 11, 2001. 
Story: http://bo.st/n4YZ86

President Obama and congressional leaders reached a deal would cut trillions from the national deficit while raising the country's debt limit.  The president conceded it is not the deal he would have preferred, but he said, "This compromise does make a serious down payment on the deficit reduction we need and gives each party a strong incentive to get a balanced plan done before the end of the year."  The agreement must pass both chambers of Congress, a prospect that still is uncertain. 
Story: http://www.boston.com/news/nation/washington/articles/2011/08/01/us_leaders_reach_deal_on_debt_passage_uncertain/?camp=fb

For a few days about every three months, Mass. Lottery's Cash WinFall may be the most reliably lucrative lottery game in the country. status_message: It's a sad situation for the Rocket, writes Dan Shaughnessy. Against the advice of just about everyone, stubborn Clemens insisted on going before Congress (in February 2008) to defend his name after he showed up 82 times in the Mitchell Report, which investigated the use of steroids in baseball  Now he faces the possibility of jail.
link_name: Clemens already in a jam before start

status_message: The Globe's Pulitzer Prize-winning art critic Sebastian Smee takes a closer look at Boston's famous Citgo sign.  He writes, "Combining simplicity and scale with coolly shifting patterns of colored light, the Citgo sign has a force and presence that even the likes of abstract and minimalist superstars like Frank Stella, Dan Flavin, and Sol LeWitt must envy."

Drawn by faith to her calling, Kip Tiernan brought unconditional love to each encounter with the homeless, and she didn't hesitate to criticize the powerful if they backed what she believed were unfair policies or tried to slide by with words of pity.
link_name: Rosie's Place founder Kip Tiernan dies at 85

status_message: Now in their ninth year, these twice-yearly, Sox-centric trips have become a highlight of Dana-Farber's patient and family outreach program - and a life-changer for those who experience them.
link_name: Teens battling cancer take a road trip to Sox game

status_message: At tomorrow's fireworks display on the Esplanade,  Eric Tucker arranges intricate launching and firing sequences of the pyrotechnics, forming a dance of sparks intended to match the pace and tone of the music. This choreography requires months of exacting work that combines design, musicianship, engineering, and chemistry.
link_name: Pyrotechnician lights Fourth music with fireworks

status_message: Senator Scott Brown fired off a letter to Stacia A. Hylton, director of the Marshals Service, urging her to find a "less costly and less extravagant'' mode of transportation for Whitey Bulger.
link_name: US defends cost of copter for 'Whitey'' Bulger

status_message: The week in photos: http://www.boston.com/bostonglobe/photos/photos_galleries/boston_globe_staff_photos_of_the_week_070111/?camp=fb
link_name: Boston Globe staff photos of the week

status_message: The Department of Health and Human Services concluded that the scientists suppressed information about the dangers to elders participating in research on how to reduce often lethal hip injuries. The regulators said the scientists should have shared their findings about the use of protective padded underwear with patients and safety boards that routinely oversee medical studies.
link_name: Elders not told of risks in hip study, US alleges

status_message: Do you ever feel like some technologies are passing you by? In today's Globe, Beth Teitell writes, "In the not-so-distant past, gray hair and orthopedic shoes made you look old. Today, there are other giveaways: an AOL address, the inability to tweet — or even find Twitter on the web. Flip phones are the new middle-age paunch."
The Fall River Police Chief said yesterday that a 9-year-old boy that Marie Joseph was watching at the pool on Sunday told police she had an accident on a water slide.
link_name: Mass. shuts 30 facilities after death in Fall River; body apparently was in state pool 3 days

status_message: If you're thinking that the Fourth would be a good time to explore how far New England wines have come, the Globe's wine columnist Stephen Meuse has some suggestions.
link_name: Wines that are rooted in New England and its history

status_message: In an op-ed column in today's Globe, criminal defense lawyer Harvey A. Silverglate writes, "The public outrage and media onslaught about William Bulger's refusal to betray his brother, James 'Whitey' Bulger, needs to stop. Bill Bulger is criticized because... he hopes never to have a part in Whitey Bulger's downfall." What do you think? Is the media being too hard on William Bulger?
link_name: It's not a crime to love a sibling

status_message: The quiet cars are located nearest the locomotive. The mandatory quiet will be imposed during peak commuting hours, from 6 to 9 a.m. and 4 to 7 p.m. on weekdays.
link_name: T rolls out 'quiet cars' on all commuter lines

status_message: Whitey Bulger also allegedly acknowledged "visiting Las Vegas on numerous occasions to play the slots," the prosecutors said, noting that Bulger claimed he had won more than he lost.
link_name: 'Whitey' Bulger allegedly visited Boston in disguise, 'armed to the teeth'

status_message: While computers, phones, and even watches have been transformed at breathtaking speed, improvements to medical devices have arrived slowly and incrementally. Now, a new center at MIT wants to bring the breakneck pace of consumer tech development to such devices, and cement the Boston region's role in that transformation.
link_name: MIT creates medical device research center

status_message: The MFA remains at the leading edge of an emerging museum practice to proactively research works with little ownership history and make amends if they are found to have been acquired under questionable circumstances. Since 2004, the MFA has returned three other works seized during World War II.
link_name: MFA makes amends in probable plundering

status_message: While living in Santa Monica, Whitey Bulger frequently drove to the border, parked on the US side and walked into Tijuana, using a false identification to get through security. In Tijuana, he was able to purchase Atenolol, a drug taken for chest pain and high blood pressure, without a prescription.
link_name: Bulger offers new details to authorities
Back in the town he terrorized

status_message: "You've got to understand something.  We're South Boston people, and when you grow up in Southie, the cardinal virtue is loyalty. . . . And you think he wouldn't be there today?''  - A friend of William Bulger explains the former UMass president's loyalty to his brother, Whitey.
link_name: Brother's loyal presence draws mobster's smile

status_message:
US Magistrate to Whitey Bulger in court today: "Can you afford a lawyer?"

"Well, I could, if you gave me my money back," Bulger said.
link_name: Feds, 'Whitey' spar over whether he has enough cash

status_message: "Suddenly, it hit Tommy Donahue, like a slap in the face, that the man who allegedly murdered his father Michael 30 years ago was finally captured." - From Kevin Cullen's latest column on Whitey Bulger's arrest.
link_name: For one family, something approaching justice

status_message: The arrest in California of Whitey Bulger is a long-sought victory for the FBI, whose reputation was sullied by its connection to the mobster and whose fruitless efforts to find the fugitive had been regarded by some with suspicion.
link_name: Whitey Bulger surrenders in Calif. after 16 years on run

status_message: Meet the Bay Cove All-Stars, a group of developmentally disabled adults who sort the bottles and cans discarded in the suites and clubs at Fenway Park and take them to a redemption center in Allston. They are here, rain or shine, every morning after a Red Sox home game.
link_name: Developmentally disabled cleanup crew pitches in at Fenway

status_message: The "I'm a Mormon'' ad campaign, a rebranding effort, overlaps with a political campaign that, for the first time, includes two Mormons who are presidential contenders — former governors Mitt Romney, who is in the race, and Jon Huntsman of Utah, who plans to announce his candidacy tomorrow.

A Globe reporter aboard one of the Duck Boats reported that Patrice Bergeron had received at least three marrige proposals from the women in the crowd. People lined the streets 20 to 50 people deep. People called out "Loooooooch"-- for Milan Lucic -- and he tipped his cap as they chanted his name.
link_name: Jubilant crowds line Boston streets for Bruins victory parade

status_message: Wednesday's Game 7 win over the Canucks was not an end so much as it was a beginning, if for no other reason than the fact that the Bruins are in position to make it so.
link_name: Freed from their past, Bruins focus on the future

status_message: Where does Bruins' title rank among century's best? The 2004 Red Sox get the gold medal, the 2001-02 Patriots deserve silver and this year's Stanley Cup champs get the bronze, according to Dan Shaughnessy.
link_name: Shaughnessy: Bruins title ranks third among the century's best

status_message: For Bruins fans who had followed the team's every twist and turn as long as they could remember, the win was a transcendent thrill, a genuine moment of catharsis they thought might never come.
link_name: Stanley Cup in hand, Bruins fans erupt

status_message: Thanks to the two-goal performances of Marchand and linemate Patrice Bergeron, as well as another spectacular performance in net by Tim Thomas (37 saves), the Boston Bruins are at last rejoicing again.

Breaking: A federal jury found former House speaker Salvatore F. DiMasi guilty on 7 of 9 charge for conspiring to help a software company win multimillion-dollar state contracts in exchange for kickbacks.
link_name: DiMasi convicted of corruption in Cognos case

status_message: So what do you do when your life hangs in the balance?  If you're former House Speaker Salvatore F. DiMasi, you circle up your family and friends, eat some food, and talk. And talk. And talk.
link_name: As jury deliberates, life hangs for DiMasi, others

status_message: Do you plug in on vacation? The Globe's Beth Teitell writes, "A new holiday stress has been added to traditional concerns about over-crowded beaches, black flies, and lousy weather. Think of it as Anxiety 4G: Is the bed-and-breakfast's wireless working, and where can I charge my phone, my laptop, my iPad, and my Kindle?"
link_name: Going on vacation is stressful... if you are not plugged in and charged up

status_message: Governor Rick Scott this month signed a law making Florida the first state to limit a physician's ability to ask patients or their parents whether they own a gun. At the heart of the issue is whether guns are a matter of public health. Supporters of the law say that they are not.

While the Democratic candidates running for Brown's Senate seat range from political unknowns to up-and-coming state lawmakers, they all share an abiding conviction that they could emerge from obscurity, with no member of Congress and no one named Kennedy standing in their way in a Democratic primary.
link_name: Democrats see opportunity in race for Brown's Senate seat

status_message: In his latest column, Kevin Cullen writes about how a teacher was punished in the aftermath of Phoebe Prince's suicide because she had the temerity to question the way her superiors handled the mess.
link_name: South Hadley High misses the point, again

status_message: "One of these days people will realize this simple fact: There is absolutely no such thing as game-to-game "momentum'' in the world of sports." -- Bob Ryan on the Bruins' loss to the Canucks
link_name: Stanley Cup Final really is one game at a time

status_message: Paul Fireman, the founder of Reebok, is investing in a Boulder start-up that specializes in $175 sneakers built to emulate a shoeless stride — yet with enough cushioning to protect skin and joints from the realities of pavement pounding.
link_name: Reebok founder Fireman returns to sneaker business with $20m stake in Colorado firm

status_message: Dan Shaughnessy: "Wouldn't the Cup make a nice hood ornament for a Duck Boat? This is how it felt around Foxborough in 2001 and around Fenway in 2004. This is how it felt when the Celtics routed and shocked the Lakers in the sixth game in 2008. The Bruins are suddenly dominating their favored foes and have the Cup well within their grasp. The Bruins outscored Vancouver 12-1 in two games here this week."
link_name: With momentum on their side, Bruins get even

status_message: The after effects of last week's tornadoes are subtly revealed in children's dreams as well as in their behavior. Some kept bags packed and ready to go in case their family had to make another quick escape. Others had separation anxiety.
link_name: Young victims grapple with life after Springfield tornado

status_message:
How can Massachusetts attract and keep young people working here?  We're sponsoring a forum on Tuesday afternoon in Boston on this issue.

Gov. Patrick will speak, as well as several prominent business leaders.  Click the link to sign up for your free tickets.
link_name: Cultivating Talent: A Building a Better Commonwealth Forum
Quick fix for I-93 bridges begins

status_message: A recent Zagat survey named service the top complaint among Boston diners. But some diners are no picnic either, and table-side interrogation is growing, according to local restaurateurs. Blame food allergies, both real and imagined, shows like "Top Chef'' — and ocean-activist Ted Danson.
link_name: When fussy diners are impossible to please

status_message: Historian David McCullough, author of "1776," "John Adams," and other great books, took a walk through the Public Garden with reporter Joseph Kahn and shared some of his favorite stops on his morning walk.  His latest book, "The Great Journey: Americans in Paris," was published last week.
link_name: Master historian relishing life in historic Hub

status_message: Mitt Romney has faced a fusillade from the right for the plan they call RomneyCare. But a look back at the birth of the Mass. law shows why he can't, and won't, back away. It was an amazing political feat, and no one's role was bigger than his.
link_name: Romney and health care: In the thick of history

status_message: Since the launch of its new Art of the Americas Wing, MFA attendance has shot up by 50 percent. Admission and membership revenue have increased by 25 percent. And more than 7,000 tours of the new wing have been conducted by museum curators and gallery instructors.
link_name: MFA keeps tweaking, adding pieces, and thinking big

status_message: Yesterday during the corruption trial of former House speaker Sal DiMasi, one more startling, if less serious, revelation dropped: Testifying under oath, Governor Deval Patrick was forced to acknowledge that his code name within the administration is Sally Reynolds.
link_name: Governor Patrick keeps his cool during a strange, historic day on stand

status_message: The price of a new knee varies widely at Boston area hospitals.  At Lowell General Hospital, insurers shelled out an average of $14,153. The typical bill for a knee replacement at Boston's Brigham and Women's Hospital: $25,284.
link_name: Stark hospital fee disparities found in Massachusetts

status_message: Wrong-sized studs to blame for the failure of two giant water pipes a year ago.
link_name: Wrong studs led to 2010 water main break, report says

status_message: JFK struggled with doubts about the expensive space program as he prepared for his reelection campaign and worried that public and congressional support was waning, according to a newly declassified tape being released today by the JFK Library.
link_name: JFK had doubts about moon landing

status_message: Globe columnist Alex Beam explains why he just doesn't love Oprah.
Massachusetts has staked out its own corner of the lucrative consumer electronics market: sophisticated chips and components found inside popular must-haves like the iPhone and iPad, both from Apple.
link_name: Parts from Mass. firms make gadget boom whole

status_message: The US FDA today approved Incivek, a hepatitis C treatment that is expected to be a blockbuster drug for Vertex Pharmaceuticals Inc. of Cambridge.
link_name: FDA approves potential blockbuster drug for Vertex

status_message: Fees could rise as much as $880 per year for the average UMass undergraduate student; that would raise the combined tuition and fees for in-state students to an average of $11,900 per year.
link_name: Faced with budget gap, UMass may raise fees again

status_message: Mass. vets report seeing an increasing number of dogs with serious infectious diseases not typically found in New England, a phenomenon they say is probably fueled by a growing number of pets rescued from Southern states.
link_name: Disease statistics raise dog adoption concerns

status_message: The 39-to-0 vote in the Mass. Senate came just eight days after a similar bill passed the House — swift movement by Beacon Hill standards — as lawmakers continue trying to distance themselves from reports that legislators had made frequent calls to help land probation jobs for friends and associates.
link_name: Massachusetts Senate tackles state job patronage

status_message: A look back: Long before the Web, The Boston Globe had a "homepage" of sorts – its old storefront downtown. Fans crowded Newspaper Row (a section of Washington Street downtown) to follow big games on the Globe's scoreboard. Hundreds "watched" the Red Sox beat the New York Giants four games to three in the 1912 World Series. (photo dated Oct. 18, 1912) More photos: http://beta.boston.com/2011/05/19/boston-globe-storefront-webpage/?camp=fb

status_message: While more taxi passengers are paying with credit cards, cabdrivers say that the mobile-payment and taxi radio dispatch companies that partnered to install the credit card devices have profited at drivers' expense, and that taking cards has made it harder, not easier, for them to earn a living.
